20110118190007.000|20110118190009.000|TR0|ALI VELSHI, CNN ANCHOR: All right.  Well, 
20110118190009.000|20110118190011.000|TR0|we've been covering the story about Apple 
20110118190011.000|20110118190013.000|TR0|for a while.  I want to tell you about a 
20110118190013.000|20110118190016.000|TR0|new development we've got.
20110118190016.000|20110118190018.000|TR0|

20110118190023.000|20110118190025.000|TR0|to Switzerland to seek treatment of a

20110118190341.000|20110118190343.000|TR0|well, that's about as huge as they get.  
20110118190343.000|20110118190346.000|TR0|They don't get any bigger.
20110118190346.000|20110118190348.000|TR0|
20110118190348.000|20110118190350.000|TR0|China is America's partner and rival, its 
20110118190350.000|20110118190353.000|TR0|banker and its supermarket.  It has the 
20110118190353.000|20110118190355.000|TR0|largest population on Earth.  It has the 
20110118190355.000|20110118190357.000|TR0|of fastest-growing economy on Earth.
20110118190357.000|20110118190400.000|TR0|
20110118190400.000|20110118190402.000|TR0|President Hu will be President Obama's 
20110118190402.000|20110118190404.000|TR0|guest at a private dinner tonight, and a 
20110118190404.000|20110118190407.000|TR0|full-on State Dinner tomorrow.  In 
20110118190407.000|20110118190409.000|TR0|between, meeting after meeting at the 
20110118190409.000|20110118190411.000|TR0|White House.
20110118190411.000|20110118190414.000|TR0|
20110118190414.000|20110118190416.000|TR0|What are they going to talk about?  Well, 
20110118190416.000|20110118190418.000|TR0|I think the question is, what won't they 
20110118190418.000|20110118190421.000|TR0|talk about?
20110118190421.000|20110118190423.000|TR0|
20110118190423.000|20110118190425.000|TR0|U.S./Chinese relations are complicated, to 
20110118190425.000|20110118190428.000|TR0|say the least.  You'll hear that word a 
20110118190428.000|20110118190430.000|TR0|lot this week, but they boil down to three 
20110118190430.000|20110118190432.000|TR0|things -- money, obviously.  The Chinese 
20110118190432.000|20110118190435.000|TR0|have a ton of it.  We don't have as much.
20110118190435.000|20110118190437.000|TR0|
20110118190437.000|20110118190439.000|TR0|They sell other countries a lot more stuff 
20110118190439.000|20110118190442.000|TR0|than they buy, and they use the proceeds 
20110118190442.000|20110118190444.000|TR0|to further their interests around the 
20110118190444.000|20110118190446.000|TR0|world. That's a fact.
20110118190446.000|20110118190448.000|TR0|
20110118190448.000|20110118190451.000|TR0|They're also investing heavily in their 
20110118190451.000|20110118190453.000|TR0|military.  In just the past week, we've 
20110118190453.000|20110118190455.000|TR0|heard about a Chinese stealth fighter jet 
20110118190455.000|20110118190458.000|TR0|and a long- range missile that could 
20110118190458.000|20110118190500.000|TR0|threaten U.S. ships in the Pacific.
20110118190500.000|20110118190502.000|TR0|
20110118190502.000|20110118190505.000|TR0|And then there's human rights.  This is an 
20110118190505.000|20110118190507.000|TR0|issue that often gets eclipsed by the 
20110118190507.000|20110118190509.000|TR0|other two.  The world got a reminder of 
20110118190509.000|20110118190512.000|TR0|Chinese repression when a pro-democracy 
20110118190512.000|20110118190514.000|TR0|dissident won the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize.  
20110118190514.000|20110118190516.000|TR0|You remember this?
20110118190516.000|20110118190519.000|TR0|
20110118190519.000|20110118190521.000|TR0|Couldn't accept it because he's in prison. 
20110118190521.000|20110118190523.000|TR0| They laid the prize on an empty chair in 
20110118190523.000|20110118190526.000|TR0|Oslo.
20110118190526.000|20110118190528.000|TR0|
20110118190528.000|20110118190530.000|TR0|Well, since I'm a money guy, let me show 
20110118190530.000|20110118190533.000|TR0|you that relationship, the business 
20110118190533.000|20110118190535.000|TR0|relationship, in a little more detail.
20110118190535.000|20110118190537.000|TR0|
20110118190537.000|20110118190540.000|TR0|China is now the third largest buyer of 
20110118190540.000|20110118190542.000|TR0|U.S. exports.  Canada is the first.  
20110118190542.000|20110118190544.000|TR0|Mexico is the second.  So, bottom line, 
20110118190544.000|20110118190547.000|TR0|$82 billion in goods last year went that 
20110118190547.000|20110118190549.000|TR0|way to China.
20110118190549.000|20110118190551.000|TR0|
20110118190551.000|20110118190554.000|TR0|Look at the other arrow, though, $334 
20110118190554.000|20110118190556.000|TR0|billion worth of goods America bought from 
20110118190556.000|20110118190558.000|TR0|China.  The major reason for that, in the 
20110118190558.000|20110118190601.000|TR0|view of many U.S. politicians, is a 
20110118190601.000|20110118190603.000|TR0|deliberately undervalued Chinese currency.
20110118190603.000|20110118190605.000|TR0|
20110118190605.000|20110118190608.000|TR0|Beijing keeps its currency, called the 
20110118190608.000|20110118190610.000|TR0|yuan -- you'll hear it pronounced many 
20110118190610.000|20110118190612.000|TR0|different ways.  That's how you pronounce 
20110118190612.000|20110118190615.000|TR0|it, the yuan.  But they keep it relatively 
20110118190615.000|20110118190617.000|TR0|cheap -- so they are accused of doing -- 
20110118190617.000|20110118190619.000|TR0|and that makes Chinese-made products 
20110118190619.000|20110118190622.000|TR0|relatively cheap in other countries versus 
20110118190622.000|20110118190624.000|TR0|products made in other places.  The same 
20110118190624.000|20110118190626.000|TR0|thing made in China, in part because of 
20110118190626.000|20110118190629.000|TR0|that currency, may be cheaper than being 
20110118190629.000|20110118190631.000|TR0|made anywhere else.
20110118190631.000|20110118190633.000|TR0|
20110118190633.000|20110118190636.000|TR0|That's not the only give and take in this 
20110118190636.000|20110118190638.000|TR0|discussion, by the way. China finances 
20110118190638.000|20110118190640.000|TR0|much of America's spending by lending the 
20110118190640.000|20110118190643.000|TR0|U.S. money. Right now it is the largest 
20110118190643.000|20110118190645.000|TR0|foreign holder of U.S. debt, almost $900 
20110118190645.000|20110118190647.000|TR0|billion worth of U.S. debt.
20110118190647.000|20110118190650.000|TR0|
20110118190650.000|20110118190652.000|TR0|So, clearly, both presidents need to 
20110118190652.000|20110118190654.000|TR0|choose their words wisely because both 
20110118190654.000|20110118190657.000|TR0|sides kind of need each other in this 
20110118190657.000|20110118190659.000|TR0|equation.
20110118190659.000|20110118190701.000|TR0|

20110118190713.000|20110118190715.000|TR0|
20110118190715.000|20110118190718.000|TR0|Jill, this is an important, important 
20110118190718.000|20110118190720.000|TR0|consideration.  We think of China, a 
20110118190720.000|20110118190722.000|TR0|communist and longtime totalitarian 
20110118190722.000|20110118190725.000|TR0|regime.  We think of the leader of China,

20110118190732.000|20110118190734.000|TR0|talk that maybe he's not.
20110118190734.000|20110118190736.000|TR0|
20110118190736.000|20110118190739.000|TR0|JILL DOUGHERTY, CNN FOREIGN AFFAIRS 
20110118190739.000|20110118190741.000|TR0|CORRESPONDENT:  Yes.  And it came up, Ali, 
20110118190741.000|20110118190743.000|TR0|just very recently, when secretary -- the 
20110118190743.000|20110118190746.000|TR0|defense secretary, Gates, was in Beijing, 
20110118190746.000|20110118190748.000|TR0|and lo and behold, just as he came, the 
20110118190748.000|20110118190750.000|TR0|military tested a fighter jet.  And the 
20110118190750.000|20110118190753.000|TR0|question -- and apparently President Hu 
20110118190753.000|20110118190755.000|TR0|did not know about that, or at least said 
20110118190755.000|20110118190757.000|TR0|that he did not know about it.
20110118190757.000|20110118190800.000|TR0|
20110118190800.000|20110118190802.000|TR0|That, of course, would raise questions.  I 
20110118190802.000|20110118190804.000|TR0|mean, is he on top of everything?  Is he 
20110118190804.000|20110118190807.000|TR0|in charge?  Or is the military taking a 
20110118190807.000|20110118190809.000|TR0|more independent line?
20110118190809.000|20110118190811.000|TR0|
20110118190811.000|20110118190814.000|TR0|And apparently, that is the case.  The 
20110118190814.000|20110118190816.000|TR0|military is speaking more aggressively, 
20110118190816.000|20110118190818.000|TR0|doing things like that.  And it raises 
20110118190818.000|20110118190821.000|TR0|some issues, you know, of where China is 
20110118190821.000|20110118190823.000|TR0|headed, who exactly controls everything.  
20110118190823.000|20110118190825.000|TR0|It's not to say, of course, that the 
20110118190825.000|20110118190828.000|TR0|president is not carrying out his 
20110118190828.000|20110118190830.000|TR0|functions, but it's just that it is a more 
20110118190830.000|20110118190832.000|TR0|aggressive tone coming from the military 
20110118190832.000|20110118190835.000|TR0|right now.
20110118190835.000|20110118190837.000|TR0|
20110118190837.000|20110118190839.000|TR0|VELSHI:  Right.  So it's how much he 
20110118190839.000|20110118190842.000|TR0|controls versus what we know of previous 
20110118190842.000|20110118190844.000|TR0|Chinese premiers controlling.       Let's 
20110118190844.000|20110118190846.000|TR0|ask this question -- there are going to be 
20110118190846.000|20110118190849.000|TR0|these meetings at the White House, a lot 
20110118190849.000|20110118190851.000|TR0|of policy meetings.  What about business? 
20110118190851.000|20110118190853.000|TR0|He's traveling with a lot of business 
20110118190853.000|20110118190856.000|TR0|leaders from China, and that's where most 
20110118190856.000|20110118190858.000|TR0|of that flow of money is coming from.
20110118190858.000|20110118190900.000|TR0|
20110118190900.000|20110118190903.000|TR0|DOUGHERTY:  Yes, exactly.  And, you know, 
20110118190903.000|20110118190905.000|TR0|it's not just the yuan, as you said, but 
20110118190905.000|20110118190907.000|TR0|it also gets into these preferential 
20110118190907.000|20110118190910.000|TR0|treatment, as the U.S. would put it, of 
20110118190910.000|20110118190912.000|TR0|Chinese companies within China, and also 
20110118190912.000|20110118190914.000|TR0|some prejudice, I guess discrimination, 
20110118190914.000|20110118190917.000|TR0|the U.S. says, against U.S. companies that 
20110118190917.000|20110118190919.000|TR0|want to operate in China.
20110118190919.000|20110118190921.000|TR0|
20110118190921.000|20110118190923.000|TR0|The big prize is the population.  You 
20110118190923.000|20110118190926.000|TR0|know, over a billion people -- just think, 
20110118190926.000|20110118190928.000|TR0|a billion customers, what you could do 
20110118190928.000|20110118190930.000|TR0|with that.  And the U.S. wants to export 
20110118190930.000|20110118190933.000|TR0|more to China.
20110118190933.000|20110118190935.000|TR0|
20110118190935.000|20110118190937.000|TR0|But there was recently, just last week, in 
20110118190937.000|20110118190940.000|TR0|fact, there was a delegation from the 
20110118190940.000|20110118190942.000|TR0|State Department, Commerce and U.S. trade 
20110118190942.000|20110118190944.000|TR0|representative, and they did not get along 
20110118190944.000|20110118190947.000|TR0|well in their discussions in Beijing.  So 
20110118190947.000|20110118190949.000|TR0|there are some frictions.  I mean, the 
20110118190949.000|20110118190951.000|TR0|U.S. wants China to open up those markets 
20110118190951.000|20110118190954.000|TR0|because it's important to the Obama 
20110118190954.000|20110118190956.000|TR0|administration --
20110118190956.000|20110118190958.000|TR0|
20110118190958.000|20110118191001.000|TR0|VELSHI:  Sure.
20110118191001.000|20110118191003.000|TR0|
20110118191003.000|20110118191005.000|TR0|DOUGHERTY:  -- to prove that something's 
20110118191005.000|20110118191008.000|TR0|moving in the relationship for American 
20110118191008.000|20110118191010.000|TR0|consumers.
20110118191010.000|20110118191012.000|TR0|
20110118191012.000|20110118191015.000|TR0|VELSHI:  Right.  A good example, General 
20110118191015.000|20110118191017.000|TR0|Motors sold more cars in China than it did 
20110118191017.000|20110118191019.000|TR0|in the United States in 2010.  But the 
20110118191019.000|20110118191022.000|TR0|reality is that national sentiment that 
20110118191022.000|20110118191024.000|TR0|favors business in China, favors Chinese 
20110118191024.000|20110118191026.000|TR0|businesses in China, isn't necessarily 
20110118191026.000|20110118191029.000|TR0|anti-American, it just favors Chinese more 
20110118191029.000|20110118191031.000|TR0|than it favors any other country.
20110118191031.000|20110118191033.000|TR0|
20110118191033.000|20110118191036.000|TR0|DOUGHERTY:  Absolutely, that's true.  And, 
20110118191036.000|20110118191038.000|TR0|you know, this administration really wants 
20110118191038.000|20110118191040.000|TR0|to prove that American consumers and also 
20110118191040.000|20110118191043.000|TR0|American business do not have a lot to 
20110118191043.000|20110118191045.000|TR0|fear from China.  You heard that coming

20110118191059.000|20110118191101.000|TR0|think she something like, if you're rowing

20110118191104.000|20110118191106.000|TR0|same direction.  And that's where China

20110118191623.000|20110118191625.000|TR0|OK.  We hear it every day.  To succeed in 
20110118191625.000|20110118191628.000|TR0|today's world, you need a college 
20110118191628.000|20110118191630.000|TR0|education.
20110118191630.000|20110118191632.000|TR0|
20110118191632.000|20110118191635.000|TR0|Many parents begin preparing for the 
20110118191635.000|20110118191637.000|TR0|expense almost the day their child is 
20110118191637.000|20110118191639.000|TR0|born.  Now, with this in mind, consider a 
20110118191639.000|20110118191642.000|TR0|new study that poses a fairly bold 
20110118191642.000|20110118191644.000|TR0|question: Are college students learning 
20110118191644.000|20110118191646.000|TR0|anything? And conclusion is that they're 
20110118191646.000|20110118191649.000|TR0|not learning all that much.
20110118191649.000|20110118191651.000|TR0|
20110118191651.000|20110118191653.000|TR0|Take a look at this pie graph.  The study 
20110118191653.000|20110118191656.000|TR0|found that 51 percent of students 
20110118191656.000|20110118191658.000|TR0|questioned spend most of their time in 
20110118191658.000|20110118191700.000|TR0|college socializing; 24 percent of the 
20110118191700.000|20110118191703.000|TR0|time is spent sleeping; 9 percent is spent 
20110118191703.000|20110118191705.000|TR0|volunteering or working; another 9 percent 
20110118191705.000|20110118191707.000|TR0|in class and labs; and 7 percent actually 
20110118191707.000|20110118191710.000|TR0|studying.  So, you take the 9 and 7, 
20110118191710.000|20110118191712.000|TR0|you've got 16 percent of the time actually 
20110118191712.000|20110118191714.000|TR0|related to school.
20110118191714.000|20110118191717.000|TR0|
20110118191717.000|20110118191719.000|TR0|The study also found that 45 percent of 
20110118191719.000|20110118191721.000|TR0|students made no major gains in learning 
20110118191721.000|20110118191724.000|TR0|after two years in college; 36 percent 
20110118191724.000|20110118191726.000|TR0|showed little change after four years; 50 
20110118191726.000|20110118191728.000|TR0|percent of those surveyed spent less time 
20110118191728.000|20110118191731.000|TR0|studying than their counterparts several 
20110118191731.000|20110118191733.000|TR0|decades ago.  But there's also this 
20110118191733.000|20110118191735.000|TR0|interesting finding.  Of the students 
20110118191735.000|20110118191738.000|TR0|questioned, they had an average GPA of 3.2.
20110118191738.000|20110118191740.000|TR0|
20110118191740.000|20110118191742.000|TR0|The study was based on transcripts, test 
20110118191742.000|20110118191745.000|TR0|scores and surveys of over 2,300 college 
20110118191745.000|20110118191747.000|TR0|students at 24 schools across the country. 
20110118191747.000|20110118191749.000|TR0| The report was based on the book 
20110118191749.000|20110118191752.000|TR0|"Academically Adrift: Limited Learning on 
20110118191752.000|20110118191754.000|TR0|College Campuses."
20110118191754.000|20110118191756.000|TR0|
20110118191756.000|20110118191759.000|TR0|The book is by a professor, by the way, at 
20110118191759.000|20110118191801.000|TR0|New York University, and another at the 
20110118191801.000|20110118191803.000|TR0|University of Virginia.  The authors argue 
20110118191803.000|20110118191806.000|TR0|that one key problem, many professors are 
20110118191806.000|20110118191808.000|TR0|spending more time publishing their own 
20110118191808.000|20110118191810.000|TR0|research than they spend in the classroom 
20110118191810.000|20110118191813.000|TR0|teaching.  And a major reason for this is 
20110118191813.000|20110118191815.000|TR0|the pressure placed on them by 
20110118191815.000|20110118191817.000|TR0|administrators to publish.
20110118191817.000|20110118191820.000|TR0|

20110118191939.000|20110118191941.000|TR0|Deng Xiao-Ping in Washington, opening the 
20110118191941.000|20110118191943.000|TR0|door to expanded relations between two 
20110118191943.000|20110118191946.000|TR0|global giants.
20110118191946.000|20110118191948.000|TR0|
20110118191948.000|20110118191950.000|TR0|In the three decades since Deng's initial 
20110118191950.000|20110118191953.000|TR0|market reforms to China's communist 
20110118191953.000|20110118191955.000|TR0|system, China has transformed itself into 
20110118191955.000|20110118191957.000|TR0|an economic powerhouse, achieving 
20110118191957.000|20110118192000.000|TR0|spectacular growth averaging 10 percent 
20110118192000.000|20110118192002.000|TR0|per year.  And with its factories humming, 
20110118192002.000|20110118192004.000|TR0|China has overtaken Germany to become the 
20110118192004.000|20110118192007.000|TR0|world's largest exporter.
20110118192007.000|20110118192009.000|TR0|
20110118192009.000|20110118192011.000|TR0|And who is China's biggest customer?  The 
20110118192011.000|20110118192014.000|TR0|U.S.
20110118192014.000|20110118192016.000|TR0|
20110118192016.000|20110118192018.000|TR0|HILLARY CLINTON, SECRETARY OF STATE:  
20110118192018.000|20110118192021.000|TR0|There was an old Chinese saying that when 
20110118192021.000|20110118192023.000|TR0|you're in the same boat, you have to row 
20110118192023.000|20110118192025.000|TR0|in the same direction.  We are in the same 
20110118192025.000|20110118192028.000|TR0|boat.  And we will either row in the same 
20110118192028.000|20110118192030.000|TR0|direction, or we will unfortunately cause 
20110118192030.000|20110118192032.000|TR0|turmoil and whirlpools that will impact 
20110118192032.000|20110118192035.000|TR0|not just our two countries, but many 
20110118192035.000|20110118192037.000|TR0|people, far beyond either of our borders.
20110118192037.000|20110118192039.000|TR0|
20110118192039.000|20110118192042.000|TR0|ROMANS:  That's because China's trading 
20110118192042.000|20110118192044.000|TR0|clout translates into financial clout.  
20110118192044.000|20110118192046.000|TR0|Today, China is by far America's biggest 
20110118192046.000|20110118192049.000|TR0|foreign creditor, holding $900 billion in 
20110118192049.000|20110118192051.000|TR0|U.S. debt.
20110118192051.000|20110118192053.000|TR0|
20110118192053.000|20110118192056.000|TR0|Another milestone, China beat out Japan in 
20110118192056.000|20110118192058.000|TR0|2010 to become the world's second largest 
20110118192058.000|20110118192100.000|TR0|economy, second only to the U.S.  But it's 
20110118192100.000|20110118192103.000|TR0|a distant second for now.  China's 
20110118192103.000|20110118192105.000|TR0|economic output last year was just 
20110118192105.000|20110118192107.000|TR0|one-third of the output of the U.S., even 
20110118192107.000|20110118192110.000|TR0|though China's population is four times as 
20110118192110.000|20110118192112.000|TR0|big, meaning China could overtake the U.S. 
20110118192112.000|20110118192114.000|TR0|in the next decade or two.
20110118192114.000|20110118192117.000|TR0|
20110118192117.000|20110118192119.000|TR0|But with the spectacular growth comes 
20110118192119.000|20110118192121.000|TR0|accusations that China doesn't play fair 
20110118192121.000|20110118192124.000|TR0|by keeping labor costs low and pegging its 
20110118192124.000|20110118192126.000|TR0|exchange rate to the dollar, making 
20110118192126.000|20110118192128.000|TR0|Chinese goods far cheaper to American 
20110118192128.000|20110118192131.000|TR0|consumers.
20110118192131.000|20110118192133.000|TR0|
20110118192133.000|20110118192135.000|TR0|But China's growth has also fueled a 
20110118192135.000|20110118192138.000|TR0|growing Chinese middle class that may be 
20110118192138.000|20110118192140.000|TR0|just as eager to spend their new wealth on 
20110118192140.000|20110118192142.000|TR0|goods and services to better their lives, 
20110118192142.000|20110118192145.000|TR0|and U.S. companies are taking notice.
20110118192145.000|20110118192147.000|TR0|
20110118192147.000|20110118192149.000|TR0|TIMOTHY GEITHNER, TREASURY SECRETARY:  The 
20110118192149.000|20110118192152.000|TR0|United States is on track to export more 
20110118192152.000|20110118192154.000|TR0|than $100 billion of goods and services to 
20110118192154.000|20110118192156.000|TR0|China this year.  Our exports to China are 
20110118192156.000|20110118192159.000|TR0|growing at twice the rate of growth of our 
20110118192159.000|20110118192201.000|TR0|exports to the rest of the world.  We have 
20110118192201.000|20110118192203.000|TR0|a great deal invested in each other's 
20110118192203.000|20110118192206.000|TR0|success.
20110118192206.000|20110118192208.000|TR0|
20110118192208.000|20110118192210.000|TR0|(END VIDEOTAPE)
20110118192210.000|20110118192213.000|TR0|
20110118192213.000|20110118192215.000|TR0|ROMANS:  Ali, there's no question about 
20110118192215.000|20110118192217.000|TR0|that, but a trade mission came back last 
20110118192217.000|20110118192220.000|TR0|week sorely disappointed that there had
